title: Update CalibrationPage with pipeline design and data sources
Run compute cost experiments for pricing
description:
Estimate compute costs before finalizing API pricing.

## Experiments needed:
- **Rules API**: Run 10K household calculations, measure avg compute time, memory, $/call
- **Predictions API**: Run 1K completions with varying # of variables (5, 10, 20), measure time per variable
- **Simulations**: Run 10M household-reforms, measure $/1M
- **Data**: Estimate monthly storage + CDN egress for projected downloads

## Questions to answer:
- What infrastructure (AWS Lambda, dedicated GPU, etc.)?
- What's target gross margin (60%? 70%)?
- Can we extrapolate from existing PE costs?

## Formula:
Price = Compute Cost / (1 - Target Margin)

## Context:
Current proposed pricing may be leaving money on the table. PE charges $0.02/call and users are fine with it. Competitors charge $0.05-0.10. We proposed $0.003-0.01 without knowing actual costs.

title: Prep for Yuri Kim / NextLadder meeting (Monday)
description:
Yuri Kim meeting prep - he's moving from Gates Foundation to NextLadder Ventures.

## Background:
- Indirectly funded PE through MyFriendBen grant ($300k of $2.1M)
- NextLadder has both philanthropic side and investment arm
- He cares about benefits access

## Key messages:
1. **For philanthropic side**: Grants to PE fund research. PE may subcontract to Cosilico for platform work. Your grants fund applications, not infrastructure.

2. **For investment side**: Cosilico is the infrastructure play. Pure platform, 100% product revenue. MyFriendBen-style apps would contract Cosilico as a vendor (not subgrant to PE).

3. **The pitch**: 'Your portfolio companies like MyFriendBen have partial customer data. They can download our rules engine for free, but it's useless without knowing the customer's full financial picture. Our predictions API completes the profile.'

## Materials:
- /thesis - investor pitch (hidden page)
- /structure - PE/Cosilico relationship explainer (hidden page)  
- /pricing - pricing details (hidden page, pending finalization)

## Questions to ask Yuri:
- What's his new focus area at NextLadder?
- Does NextLadder's investment arm look at infrastructure plays?
- Would he intro to investment side if philanthropic fit isn't right?

title: Create VC outreach list with contact info
description: Compile list of target VCs with partner names, emails, and warm intro paths. Tier 1: OSS Capital, Ribbit, QED. Tier 2: a16z Infra, General Catalyst, Index. Tier 3: First Round, Obvious.

title: Team communication: PE/Cosilico structure
description:
Announce the PE/Cosilico transition to the PolicyEngine team.

## Timing: Early January 2025

## Key messages:
- PE is becoming more focused on research and impact
- Infrastructure moves to Cosilico (sustainable through commercial revenue)
- Same founding team, same mission, cleaner structure
- Technical folks → Cosilico (equity upside potential)
- Policy folks → PE (mission-focused, less infra burden)

## Questions to anticipate:
- Is PE going away? → No, more focused
- What happens to my role? → Technical vs policy split
- When does this happen? → Gradual, not a cliff

## Prep:
- Have 1:1s scheduled for follow-up questions
- Be ready with specifics on who goes where
- Consider equity/comp implications for Cosilico roles

## Note:
Yuri Kim knows (Monday meeting) - he's trusted to keep confidential until announcement.

title: Identify and reach out to design partners
description: Contact potential design partners: AI-native fintech (Ramp, Brex), benefits platforms (Justworks, Rippling), financial planning AI (Monarch, Copilot), benefits navigators (Propel, SingleStop)

title: Finish Canada model (50% → 100%)
description: Complete PolicyEngine Canada implementation for international expansion story

title: Finalize Cosilico API pricing
description:
After compute cost experiments (cosilico.ai-44f), finalize pricing for all products.

## Current thinking:
- **Rules API**: ~$0.02/call (match PE, proven acceptable)
- **Predictions API**: TBD - depends on per-variable vs per-completion model
- **Full Profile**: Rules + Predictions bundled
- **Simulations**: Lower price, mission priority (~$0.25/1M household-reforms)
- **Data downloads**: $0.10/GB

## Pricing principles:
- Everything open source, pay for computed insights
- Generous free tier (mission alignment)
- No bulk discounts (KISS, like AI companies)
- Start at/near PE pricing, still 5-10x below competitors

## Depends on:
- cosilico.ai-44f (compute cost experiments)

description: Prepare materials and outreach for $3-5M seed round

title: Document PE/Cosilico structure and transition plan
description:
Capture the PE → Cosilico transition structure for different stakeholders.

## Structure summary:

### Cosilico (For-Profit, C-Corp or PBC)
- AI statute-to-code generator
- Microsimulation engine  
- Prediction APIs
- Dataset calibration & freshness
- Commercial API hosting
- Revenue: API usage, data subscriptions, enterprise

### PolicyEngine (501(c)(3) Nonprofit)
- Custom policy interactives
- Research partnerships
- Grant-funded analysis
- Policy education
- Revenue: Grants, research contracts

## Relationship:
- PE is a customer of Cosilico (at-cost APIs)
- PE may subcontract to Cosilico when grants require platform work
- Same founding team runs both (for now)
- Technical people → Cosilico, Policy people → PE

## Money flows:
- Philanthropic: Grant → PE → may subcontract to Cosilico
- Investment: Portfolio cos (like MyFriendBen) → contract Cosilico directly

## Open questions:
- When/how to split team?
- CEO for each org long-term?
- How to maintain PE's 'Cosilico expertise' advantage over time?

## Created pages:
- /structure - audience-specific explainer (investors, funders, partners)

title: Break up App.tsx into separate components
description: App.tsx in cosilico.ai is ~2600 lines. Split into separate page components (LandingPage, Architecture, Demo, etc.) for maintainability.
